awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding Plasma-Liquid Interactions Through Controlled Plasma-Microdroplet Experiments and Modeling
awd_abstract_narration:
This collaborative research project between University of Minnesota-Twin Cities and University of Michigan-Ann Arbor will study the interaction of a water droplet with an atmospheric pressure plasma - a reactive gas of neutral atoms and molecules, charged radicals and ions, and electrons. Chemically reactive liquids are used throughout society, from cleaning fluids in the home to customized solutions for pharmaceutical manufacturing; and now increasingly in biomedical applications.  Customizing the reactivity of these liquids is a challenge, particularly when the active species have short lifetimes. Atmospheric pressure plasmas are an ideal medium to produce chemical reactivity; and plasma-liquid interactions leverage the ability to generate chemically reactive species in plasmas to produce unique chemical reactivity in the liquid.  This project will also develop and support an annual one-week US Low Temperature Plasma School aimed to provide opportunities for graduate students from across the country to be immersed in low temperature plasma science and learn from leading researchers in their field.

In this research project, the interaction of a single water droplet with a controlled diffuse cold atmospheric pressure plasma will be investigated with the goal of quantifying the reaction of plasma produced species with liquids.  The reaction kinetics occurring near the boundary between the gas plasma and liquid, resulting in interfacial transport, becomes increasingly complex when transport and reactivity are highly coupled. This is often the case when transport includes short-lived highly reactive species as in both the plasma and liquid phases, and species transfer is transport limited. Plasma activation of aerosols and small liquid droplets interspersed in the gas plasma provides opportunities to reduce transport limits to a minimum.  The experimental apparatus at University of Minnesota will uniquely enable the investigation of plasma interactions with a single droplet of known initial and final composition, passing through a well-characterized plasma. Multi-phase plasma modeling at University of Michigan will comprehensively address this complex system. The anticipated results will, in particular, elucidate droplet charging, plasma induced droplet evaporation, transport mechanisms of short-lived species and convective transport effects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Innovations at the Nexus of Food-Energy-

por.por_cntn:
Plasmas – ionized gases – are a source of chemically reactive species.  For example, plasma production of ozone is the major method of purifying water in municipal water systems.  Plasmas are able to chemically active liquids due to the ability for the plasma produced radical and ions to solvate into the liquid.  Activating small water droplets is particularly efficient due to their large surface area-to-volume ratio.  Dispersing and chemically activating liquid droplets in atmospheric pressure plasmas have many environmental, manufacturing and agricultural applications, from sanitation and material synthesis to fertilizer production.  With small droplets dispersed in the plasma, there are complex interactions that occur between the charged particles in the plasma and the activation of the droplet.  These complexities then challenge optimizing plasma-liquid interactions for industrial applications.

In this project, fundamental plasma interactions between liquid droplets and atmospheric pressure plasmas were experimentally and computationally investigated with the goal of translating that knowledge to the development of society benefiting technologies using chemically activated aerosols.  Advances were made in our fundamental understanding of the plasma-droplet interactions, the manner in which plasma produced species enter into and activate the droplets and how plasmas can be configured to optimize the activation. The investigations were extended to other configurations for plasma activation of liquids, including microfluidic channels as used in labs-on-a-chip and those used for plasma activated solution electrochemistry.  In addition to improving our ability to use plasma activation of liquids, and aerosols in particular, for biomedical, materials, environmental and agricultural applications, new experimental diagnostics and computational methods were developed to investigate multi-phase plasmas. These techniques and methods are broadly applicable to the field of low temperature plasmas.

The project supported the development and delivery of the United States Low Temperature Plasma Summer School (USLTPSS).  The USLTPSS is a week-long comprehensive introduction to the field of low temperature plasmas intended for graduate students, post-doctoral researchers, and early career professionals who are new to the field.  The 2nd USLTPSS was attended by nearly 100 students, who participated in lectures, post-sessions, demonstrations and hands-on experiences. 

 


Last Modified: 04/02/2024
Modified by: Mark J Kushner

Plasmas  ionized gases  are a source of chemically reactive species. For example, plasma production of ozone is the major method of purifying water in municipal water systems. Plasmas are able to chemically active liquids due to the ability for the plasma produced radical and ions to solvate into the liquid. Activating small water droplets is particularly efficient due to their large surface area-to-volume ratio. Dispersing and chemically activating liquid droplets in atmospheric pressure plasmas have many environmental, manufacturing and agricultural applications, from sanitation and material synthesis to fertilizer production. With small droplets dispersed in the plasma, there are complex interactions that occur between the charged particles in the plasma and the activation of the droplet. These complexities then challenge optimizing plasma-liquid interactions for industrial applications.


In this project, fundamental plasma interactions between liquid droplets and atmospheric pressure plasmas were experimentally and computationally investigated with the goal of translating that knowledge to the development of society benefiting technologies using chemically activated aerosols. Advances were made in our fundamental understanding of the plasma-droplet interactions, the manner in which plasma produced species enter into and activate the droplets and how plasmas can be configured to optimize the activation. The project supported the development and delivery of the United States Low Temperature Plasma Summer School (USLTPSS). The USLTPSS is a week-long comprehensive introduction to the field of low temperature plasmas intended for graduate students, post-doctoral researchers, and early career professionals who are new to the field.
